Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: A home loan repayment is due in two months, and the father needs to prepare for it
Expectation2: Respond to emails and messages within a reasonable time frame
Situation2: The team awaits a clarification before progressing with a shared task.
Story: I sat at my desk, my phone buzzing with new emails from the team. They were waiting for my input on the project, and I knew every minute I delayed was holding them back. My manager had just sent a reminder: “Please respond ASAP so we can move forward.” I glanced at the spreadsheet open on my laptop, the numbers for our home loan repayment staring back at me. Two months left, and I needed to double-check our finances, maybe even call the bank to discuss options. My wife had texted earlier, worried about the upcoming payment. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in—my family counting on me to keep us secure, my colleagues relying on me to keep the workflow moving. My heart pounded as I stared at the blinking cursor in my draft email, torn between opening the banking app or hitting send. The pressure built, and I wondered how I could possibly meet everyone’s expectations at once.
